106568: Mimeofacture.author: majinara
106568: Mimeofacture.text_parsed:
The card is just too random. You need to have this card in your hand, a lot of mana available, your opponent must have permanents in play that are worth getting the copies of, and your opponent must have multiple copies of those permanents in his deck AND still left in his library (not in hand, graveyard, play, exiled or whatnot).
That's too many "if"s, even though killing legends this way could be fun.

Also, the card is best when you use it on stuff that is expensive and powerful. But the more expensive a card is, the more unlikely it is that your opponent will have a lot of them in his deck.

106576: Giant Solifuge.author: achilleselbow
106576: Giant Solifuge.text_parsed: This is basically a weaker version of Yavimaya Ants without the upkeep. Not sure if it's better - creatures with 1 toughness usually don't stick around long enough for upkeep to be a problem, and it has 1 less power. The shroud is nice, but that does mean you can't Giant Growth or Rancor it, and I don't know how likely it would be that your opponent would try to blast it anyway when he can just chump block. I guess I'm partial to the ants since they were in my first deck ever, but both are pretty good.

Don't be fooled, this thing did its fair share of smashing. It saw play in a good many competitive decks of the time.
In the context in which it existed, lowering CMC and/or raising power would have been problematic. Plus, its worth noting that this has an incredibly flexible mana cost when compared to a hybrid like Boggart Ram-Gang, which can really only be supported by a red, green, or red/green deck.
Also, love the name Cap'n Tickles :)

106576: Giant Solifuge.author: Gabriel422
106576: Giant Solifuge.text_parsed: Was a really powerful card, and one that I absolutely loved. Too often this is a Lightning Blast to the face first, followed by the opponent's desperated attempt to find something to block it. All its power came from its shroud - the safest way to deal with a Ball Lightning is to save a Bolt for it, but the Bolt would stay dead against Giant Solifuge. Blockers have always been the poor man's choice, as they can be burned or even Frenzied away, but they are the only choice when it comes to stopping this beast. And then it's 4 to the dome, threatening to at least trample over with another 4, and that's when they do manage to get a decent blocker.

Good for EDH if your group approves of using Nephilim as Generals (I've read its done occasionally). Scary cool flavor and a strong card besides. Really good with buyback cards. Blue and Black means you get insane card draw. Card Draw is really what matters with this guy, so you can draw into extra spells. A "Spirit" deck would be nice too (see: Kamigawa), as there are lots of rewards for playing Spirit spells and he has all the best colors for spirits.

Fate Transfer works nicely in case he gets killed.

He should be Errata'd be a legend in my opinion, for both flavor and functionality as an EDH general. We need a 4 colored EDH general!

107090: Witch-Maw Nephilim.author: DarthParallax
107090: Witch-Maw Nephilim.text_parsed:
Part 5/5

For the three colors most awesome at Library Stuffs: {B}{U}{G} AND the three colors most awesome at Life Point Stuffs {B}{W}{G}, it's not so much that this Nephilim's abilities are 'out of color' (they're actually more in line than Yore-Tiller's, since it may AT first not seem very Black, but being such an Aggressive Attacker feels pretty Vorosh-y- it wouldn't be nearly this un-peaceful if it were straight Bant!....or at least it would have either or both of Wings and Sword.)



But, still, this Nephilim is not playing to it's best Strengths as much as it could. I like that it gets itself to care about and change it's Power a lot, (it's got a bit of Simic going on with those +1/+1 counters), but I still think it should somehow mention cards, or life.

I suggested on Yore-Tiller Nephilim that the ability should be tweaked from a Graveyard based one to an Exile based one, and that DEFINITELY reads much cleaner to me as actually being pretty darn good flavor for the Color Alignment. At least as good as Dune-Brood, I'd say, who I'd stake the claim was the most Flavorful of the original Nephilim, unless it tied with Ink-Treader.

Glint-Eye pulls it's weight. It's not the most flavorful or the least. It makes more sense to me than Yore-Treader and Witch-Maw as-written, in fact....I'd bet it's mechanics make the most sense to most people at first glance. This one and Dune-Brood probably tie for grokkability.

but Yore-Treader and Witch-Maw have a lot more potential to be better. Dune-Brood is very close to not needing anything functional changes beyond just getting "Pushed" (see the difference between Ghost Council of Orzhova and Obzedat, the Ghost Council)


Please don't react to one Nephilim comment of mine unless you've read at least 2 of them.

107091: Dune-Brood Nephilim.author: DarthParallax
107091: Dune-Brood Nephilim.text_parsed:
Part 1/5

The Nephilim are Crazy. Personally, I think that we need someone willing to be a Rebel and a Revolutionary in R&D, or the Rules Team, or the DCI, or the Commander Council (whatever they call themselves officially, they should start calling themselves the Commander Council). Who determines and writes the Errata? we need them too.

The Nephilim should be reprinted, given Errata, and become LEGENDARY, and they ALSO deserve to get subtypes--- they are way beyond being "Warriors" or "Wizards" though--- something more like "Beast" or "Nightmare" or "Giant" or "Spirit" or "Titan"-- something that will let them have a little bit more cohesiveness to their identity, something to pull them closer to the rest of the Creatures of the Game, while retaining their Uniqueness and Specialness as much as possible. The Eldrazi are an excellent Tribe to compare them to, because we likely won't see any more Eldrazi, but IF we did, and if R&D chose to let some of them have Subtypes, we know what kinds of subtypes we'd want to see: Nightmares, Horrors, and Giants would be appropriate, and wouldn't feel like they're ''ruining'' how Unique and Weird and Special being an Eldrazi is.

Continued Commentary on Ink-Treader Nephilim

Awesome way of doing ridiculous things to every creature on the board.

- @Iondragonx: Pongify = Turns a game of magic into something really hilarious xD.

107092: Ink-Treader Nephilim.author: 3cheesed
107092: Ink-Treader Nephilim.text_parsed:
Another very cool thing about this card that I realized is that it synergizes very well with Splice onto Arcane. Toss out a Psychic Puppetry onto Ink-Treader. Then, you can splice on a cantrip effect with Evermind, Get a million little tokens with Spiritual Visit (and targets for your next spells), a bunch of creatures (if you had any) withThrough the Breach, mill the opponent for a billion with Dampen Thought, or have a bunch of red mana with Desperate Ritual.

Like, I don't see why people haven't thought of this before!

107092: Ink-Treader Nephilim.author: sarroth
107092: Ink-Treader Nephilim.text_parsed:
They're never going to errata these guys to be legendary. But if that's stopping you making a Commander deck with one at the helm, you don't know Commander/EDH very well. It's about having fun, both making decks and in playing, and the rules given by the Rules Committee are a guideline to be followed by each group to their own discretion; ask the people you play with if they wouldn't mind you running a deck with this as its Commander/General. If they say it's okay, go build it. If they don't, well, shucks. Just remember if they do say yes and you build it to treat it as if it's legendary then, because that's what you wanted. As in, Spitting Image will make you sacrifice him and the copy you get of him. That'll still give you copies of everything else, though, so it might be worth it!

This one is my favorite. The others seem to similar to cards already out there; while this guy is similar to Radiate or Hive Mind (cards I love as well), those aren't creatures, so he still is doing a unique effect.

107092: Ink-Treader Nephilim.author: DarthParallax
107092: Ink-Treader Nephilim.text_parsed:
Part 2/5

I don't know whether all 5 Nephilim should get the same subtype, or all 5 get different subtypes. That would be an interesting debate. Probably, if you left it to a room for a vote, they'd be stuck at being just Nephilim, but the pros outweigh the cons when you consider that every single little card that supports Obscure and Crazy types (like Horror and Nightmare in particular) would be a MASSIVE boon to Nephilim EDH decks, even just to give them Flavorful companions with little mechanical significance, and Designing basically any set or even almost any product with Nephilim EDH in mind is nearly impossible beyond just making 4-colored Lands.

Another thing to Consider- 4-color Identities are just Weird. They're very hard to parse, and you can't expect a 4-color card's mechanical connection to it's identity look the same as a 5-Colored one, a 3-colored one, or a 2-colored one.

2-colored cards Very Obviously have extremely blatant mechanical references to their Colors. The flavor comes almost purely from the Melvin-ness of seeing "Yeah. That Color Pie space definitely gets those mechanics", and then just imagining the personality of someone that would use those tools.

3-colored cards get more abstract than 2-colored ones, but are still concrete. They aren't limited to Guilds, or Wedges, or Shards, or Coalition factions. They build on the identities of the Color Combinations, and very often invent new mechanical space or else draw on less-often used mantle and crust space as they need it. 3-colored cards generally feel very fleshed out, like a Wizard or Dragon with some obvious intentions for The World or for Their Life and a Modus Operandi they follow to get their way. They're definitely Big Thinkers, but everything they do makes sense. (See Nekusar: "Wheel" Tribal", and Kaalia: Big Flying Destruction Tribal for places where the Flavor gets more Ideological than Tactical because having access to an additional number of colors gives them a broader view)

5-colored is both As Concrete AND as Abstract as you can get. It's Omnipotence, Omniscience, God-Complex, Reality-affecting or just Battlefield-dominating. It usually hacks your deck (Cascade) but not always, sometimes it hacks the battlefield (Slivers), and when it hacks both at once is when it feels most 5-colored (Maelstrom Archangel, 1996 World Champion, and Scion of the Ur-Dragon).
*************************************************************************************************************************

The number of different ways you can cut up and reorganize a 4-color Identity is nuts.

It's SIX dual-colors.
It's 4 single-colors.
It's 2 Shard Triplets.
It's 2 Wedge Triplets.

It's not QUITE "5-colored minus one color", because there are enough missing Guilds, Shards, and Wedges in each of their identities to make the Nephilim actually very different from each other.

But they get VERY abstract-- abstract enough to compare them to the Psychographics (Melvin, Timmy, Vorthos, Johnny, Spike), or to Schools of Archetypes, (like Aggro, Midrange, Tempo, Control, Combo, Disruption)-- at least in terms of how impossible it is to capture the mechanics that such creatures would appropriately want and need with the kind of directness and simple Common Color Mechanics that dual-colored cards have the luxury of. You just WON'T see a Top-Down 4-colored card.

They're about a Vague Attitude or Sensibility.

Dune-Brood is the Blue-less one, so it's strengths are going to probably remind you of Blue's Weaknesses, but all kinds of things could be added to or changed about the card while remaining true to that. I think the most important thing about 4-colored Creatures is that, to help them feel Weird and Really Distinct from other color sets, you have to actively AVOID using 'classic' Color-Related mechanics, like

Countering spells
Random Discard
Direct Damage

and opt instead for the mechanics that are bled THE most throughout the Colors-- like casting spells, gaining life, making tokens, and drawing cards. Having Power and Toughness. Finding ways to use those tools mechanically, and STILL give them identities (Fast? Slow? Big? Tough? Aggressive? Peaceful?) is the kind of challenge that taxes pretty much every possible corner of your mind that can be used to make cards o_O

The only keywords I'd risk on them are keywords that you would feel comfortable putting on a common card without reminder text in a Core Set.
***********************************************************************************************************************

But all in all, the VERY strange demands that Designing and Developing them ask of your analytical and imaginative sides make them EVEN MOAR AWESOME!!!!!! :D


Continued Commentary on Glint-Eye Nephilim

107092: Ink-Treader Nephilim.author: The_Murderauder
107092: Ink-Treader Nephilim.text_parsed:
Let's break this down a little bit to see exactly how it works, and how we can take advantage of that.

First off, the ability only triggers "if that spell targets only Ink-Treader Nephilim". If the spell targets anything else, even if it's not a creature, we get no bonus. Into the Maw of Hell, for example, targets a creature and a land, so it would not copy.

A spell, can, however, refer to multiple objects as long as it targets only one of them. Searing Blood, for example, targets only one creature, but will deal damage to a player later in the turn, without targeting them.

You can copy a spell that allows you to select multiple targets, as long as the original copy targets only the Nephilim. You could copy an entwined Dream's Grip, for example, as long as you selected the Nephilim as both of the targets for the initial spell. (Note that this does not work with cards that require you to select different targets, such as Arc Trail, it only works with cards that allow you to select multiple targets, or the same target multiple times)

The second clause is that when a spell is copied for each creature, "Each copy targets a different one of those creatures." You could not, for example, cast Giant Growth, get 10 copies, then give a single creature +30/+30.

Following the example above, however, you could cast an entwined Dream's Grip (choosing the Nephilim as both the targets off the bat), get extra copies (the copies are also entwined), which each allow you to select multiple targets, only one of which has to be another creature (specifically, the creature the copy was assigned to).

If, say, there were 10 creatures on the board in addition to the Nephilim, you would get 10 taps and 10 untaps, only half of which must be assigned to specific creatures. You could tap all their creatures, untap all yours, then tap some lands, untap others, maybe tap your Howling Mine before your turn ends...

This works very well with divisible burn spells like Rolling Thunder or Pyrotechnics, getting you tons of copies that can be almost entirely redirected at your opponent's face.

Other exploitable options are spells that do a lot of different things, but only target a single creature. Fiery Gambit is an excellent example of this.
107092: Ink-Treader Nephilim.text_posted:
Let's break this down a little bit to see exactly how it works, and how we can take advantage of that.

First off, the ability only triggers "[b]if that spell targets only Ink-Treader Nephilim[/b]". If the spell targets [i]anything[/i] else, even if it's not a creature, we get no bonus. [autocard]Into the Maw of Hell[/autocard], for example, targets a creature [i]and[/i] a land, so it would not copy.

A spell, can, however, refer to multiple objects as long as it [i]targets[/i] only one of them. [autocard]Searing Blood[/autocard], for example, targets only one creature, but will deal damage to a player later in the turn, without targeting them.

You can copy a spell that allows you to select multiple targets, as long as the original copy targets only the Nephilim. You could copy an entwined [autocard]Dream's Grip[/autocard], for example, as long as you selected the Nephilim as [i]both of the targets[/i] for the initial spell. (Note that this does not work with cards that [i]require[/i] you to select [i]different[/i] targets, such as [autocard]Arc Trail[/autocard], it only works with cards that [i]allow[/i] you to select multiple targets, or the same target multiple times)

The second clause is that when a spell is copied for each creature, "[b]Each copy targets a different one of those creatures.[/b]" You could not, for example, cast [autocard]Giant Growth[/autocard], get 10 copies, then give a single creature +30/+30.

Following the example above, however, you could cast an entwined [autocard]Dream's Grip[/autocard] (choosing the Nephilim as both the targets off the bat), get extra copies (the copies are also entwined), which each allow you to select multiple targets, [i]only one of which has to be another creature[/i] (specifically, the creature the copy was assigned to).

If, say, there were 10 creatures on the board in addition to the Nephilim, you would get 10 taps and 10 untaps,   only half of which must be assigned to specific creatures. You could tap all their creatures, untap all yours, then tap some lands, untap others, maybe tap your [autocard]Howling Mine[/autocard] before your turn ends...

This works very well with divisible burn spells like [autocard]Rolling Thunder[/autocard] or [autocard]Pyrotechnics[/autocard], getting you tons of copies that can be almost entirely redirected at your opponent's face.

Other exploitable options are spells that do a lot of different things, but only target a single creature. [autocard]Fiery Gambit[/autocard] is an excellent example of this.

107093: Yore-Tiller Nephilim.author: DarthParallax
107093: Yore-Tiller Nephilim.text_parsed:
Part 4/5:

Part 1: Dune-Brood Nephilim
Part 2: Ink-Treader Nephilim
Part 3: Glint-Eye Nephilim
Part 5: Witch-Maw Nephilim

This is one of the more disappointing Nephilim Designs, because it's very difficult to see any {U} in it, OR any Esper, or any Grixis. It does make decent Numot and Oros sense, and Nephilim color identities are VERY tricky to get right without stepping on each other. I think if it gave Flying instead of pseudo-Haste it would certainly feel Blue-er, but that is probably too much. Maybe making it a Spirit-type when it comes back? Word space getting iffy?

What I like about Dune-Brood's mechanic is that it's the most Earthy-colored, it makes Sand Tokens so it's funny to pair with Hazezon Tamar, and the Sand Tokens actually don't feel out of place on a half-Jund, half-Naya beast at all. It wants to crush you, and without any {U}, the dryness of the Sand and the way some {B} producing lands are often things like Salt Flats (deserty, or at least non-fertile lands) actually makes the colors almost seem like all 4 are coming together well enough. As well as 4 colors can.

Ink-Treader Nephilim is another great one because White often likes to check when spells target creatures, usually attackers or blockers, but in general making sure that it counts only spells that target Ink-Treader Nephilim itself feels like a great way to splice {G}{W}{R} Heroic-trigger flavor from THEROS of all places, onto the {R}{U}{G} ''I like to cast spells like a Madman" Intet and Riku flavor.

Yore-Tiller here has a good illustration for a {G}{W}{U} creature, it really just needed just a bit more blazing radiance at the halo and to extend that to its torso to make it perfectly drawn. Wait, it's {B}, not {G}? Even so, it IS one of the most well-drawn for its colors. I am not sure how I would improve this card, but I do think I'd want to tweak it. It's possible that this color-alignment I would choose for doing something with Artifacts? Or Lands?

If this one's trigger had just been the Ophidian one, it would have felt like there was a tiny bit of Blue SOMEWHERE, but right now it feels like that fourth color is literally doing nothing at all, since Blue gets entirely different card types, this creature doesn't fly, there's no drawing of cards, or anything.
But at the same time, being able to make all FIVE Nephilim feel even ROUGHLY like they're using ALL FOUR of their colors is, like, a kind of monstrous task. Could this one's toughness been greater than it's power?

Maybe a Mythic Rare Updated Legendary Nephilim in these colors today would let you Exile cards from your graveyard or library and cast them that turn if they were a creature. That feels a LOT better for 'is this using all the colors enough?' at least. some kind of thing that lets you search your library for a card to exile from it and causes you to shuffle.

107093: Yore-Tiller Nephilim.author: TexasDice
107093: Yore-Tiller Nephilim.text_parsed:
I really like this one.

"Into play tapped and attacking": Feels a tiny bit like red (pseudo haste) and definitely like white, if you think about cards like Brimaz, King of Oreskos, Hero of Bladehold or Geist of Saint Traft.
Similarities with Kaalia of the Vast and the Ninjustsu mechanic inclusive. It's mostly a white thing, but I does appear in other colors (even green) too.

"From your graveyard": Reanimator things are mostly blacks ground, but white is also somewhat known for reanimation effects like Defy Death or Karmic Guide.
Also, don't forget the Unearth mechanic from Alara, which also interacts in a similar fashion to this card AND uses three of this Nephilims colors.
107093: Yore-Tiller Nephilim.text_posted:
I really like this one. 

[i]"Into play tapped and attacking"[/i]: Feels a tiny bit like red (pseudo haste) and definitely like white, if you think about cards like [autocard]Brimaz, King of Oreskos[/autocard], [autocard]Hero of Bladehold[/autocard] or [autocard]Geist of Saint Traft[/autocard]. 
Similarities with [autocard]Kaalia of the Vast[/autocard] and the Ninjustsu mechanic inclusive. It's mostly a white thing, but I does appear in other colors (even green) too.

[i]"From your graveyard"[/i]: Reanimator things are mostly blacks ground, but white is also somewhat known for reanimation effects like [autocard]Defy Death[/autocard] or [autocard]Karmic Guide[/autocard]. 
Also, don't forget the Unearth mechanic from Alara, which also interacts in a similar fashion to this card AND uses three of this Nephilims colors.

107094: Glint-Eye Nephilim.author: scumbling1
107094: Glint-Eye Nephilim.text_parsed: Glint-Eye is probably the least impressive of all the Nephilim. It doesn't have a real grandiose ability, like Radiating spells or spitting out gross amounts of tokens. It has a very self-synergistic ability, and I like that. But I think what really hurts it is adding that one colorless mana to the activated ability. Would it have made a four-color, four-mana 2/2 a complete game-breaker to make it a little more similar to Wild Mongrel? I seriously doubt it. But it would have improved the card a lot for the Johnny crowd, wanting to abuse this cycle of creatures.

107094: Glint-Eye Nephilim.author: DarthParallax
107094: Glint-Eye Nephilim.text_parsed:
Part 3/5

Part 1: Dune-Brood Nephilim
Part 2: Ink-Treader Nephilim

Ink-Treader, Dune-Brood, and Glint-Eye I think have some of the best mechanics of the Nephilim, but the one thing I'm not sure if I like is that the triggers for all the Nephilim are jumbled, but they're not FIVE different triggers.

One to trigger on Dies? (non-Black) MUST

One to trigger on Spells cast? (non-Blue)
One to trigger on Enters Battlefield? (non-Green)
One to trigger on Attacks? (non-Red)
One to trigger on Combat Damage? (non-White)

^these 4 you could rearrage in a few different ways. Ophidian for the non-Blue, Attacks for White, Combat Damage for Red, for example.

Or Enters the Battlefield for White, Combat Damage for Green, Attacks for Red, Spells cast for Blue

Or Attacks for Green, Enters the Battlefield for Red, Spells for Blue, Combat Damage for White.

**********************************************************************************************************************

I feel like having these Weird Trigger abilities is the best way to go with them. I also feel like there's a TINY bit of room to make Moar Nephilim cards. NOT A LOT. But a little.

Since a Recon Errata to make them Legendary is not likely (they HAVE the power, or someone does, but they're choosing mostly not to use it-- or not to use it YET, probably because they don't want to do it unless it becomes absolutely necessary)

Nephilim are a race of ancient beings from Ravnica, MUCH like the Eldrazi are a race of ancient beings that live on Zendikar (besides Nephilim not being planar travel-capable and thus definitely being native to Ravnica) In the Original Ravnica Block story, Niv-Mizzet SUPPOSEDLY fought and killed the Last Four of them.

Two Things:

In EITHER Ravnica's distant Future or distant Past, it would be QUITE easy to write in that the Nephilim aren't extinct after all. So IF you have the chops to make cards for them, fitting New Nephilim into the Story would be easy.

Second, to make MYTHIC Rare Nephilim, we'd want to capture just about Exactly something "Greater than a Titan, smaller than Progenitus"

They require FOUR colors of mana concentration to summon! they're EPIC. BUT, Progenitus is definitely more powerful than, say, any two of them. (The Five put together would take more than Progenitus to put down. Maybe all 5 Praetors, or Progenitus plus a Parun or two have the Power to do it. Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker would need very little assistance, but he'd need SOMETHING. He'd have it, because he's GREAT at finding pawns, having ancient spells and artifacts, and stuff like that. Remember, imagine Big, Cool, Mythic Rare Legends like we always wanted. This is roughly the Power terms we need to speak in.)

TO THAT END: The New, Mythic Rare, Legendary Nephilim could have a CMC of 8, with a Progenitus-style casting cost: CCDDEEFF. OR, maybe a Reaper King style? Would that be acceptable? You could technically cast them for colorless, but they'd all cost more than Emrakul by a mana? That seems. Doable.? It would help their combat stats for sure!

Continued Commentary on Yore-Tiller Nephilim

107095: Sword of the Paruns.author: DarthParallax
107095: Sword of the Paruns.text_parsed:
Rakdos the Defiler, Lord of Riots: the oldest, most consistent, most powerful Guild Leader. A Parun.
Niv-Mizzet the Firemind, Dracogenius: probably the second-oldest Parun.

Svogthos, the Restless Tomb: Golgari's Guildmaster history is wierd. Being what they are, I'm not sure a Golgari guildmaster has ever been really destroyed. Svogthos I believe was their representative in the original Guildpact spell.
Szadek, Lord of Secrets: No doubt one of the oldest beings on Ravnica (or Argyrem now), but I think not a very great deal older than Isperia. Certainly younger than Rakdos, but nearly as powerful because has brain.

Obzedat and Azor: the Ghost Council of Orzhova is probably both the most rotating but the least changing Guildmaster on Ravnica, and is as stale and dead as ever. It's kind of Rakdos' THING to be wild and crazy and so Rakdos himself breaking Rakdos Traditions IS Traditional.....xP Nothing like that for Orzhov. Policies have been the same damned bad deals forever. Grand Arbiter is a title of the original successorship of Azorius Senate's leadership, Azor was the first. The title is now Supreme Judge, and if you're looking for 'oldest, most powerful, and most authoritative creatures on Ravnica', the Isperia woudn't be a bad case.
Razia, Boros Archangel is probably the most powerful and oldest non-Planeswalker to ever outright get murdered in the MTG storyline that I've heard of. If you have knowledge of even higher ranked Heroes meeting untimely ends, she ranks up there at least as high as Gil-Galad. But not, maybe, as high as Ecthelion who 1v.1'd the Chief Balrog in Gondolin.

Momir Vig may have been the Parun of Simic, but I can't confirm or deny it. His guildmastership was marked as being quite similar to Niv-Mizzet's (the Guild was his toy that he made in his own image). As an elf, he could conceivably have been old enough, but 10,000 is long even for them, so maybe not.

No clue who the Gruul or Selesnya Paruns might have been. Well, the Selesnya Parun might just be "The Force according to Ravnican Jedi".

The Paruns of the Guildpact are probably some of the most powerful beings in the Multiverse that aren't Planeswalkers, and for all we know, some of them have the possibility of being Planeswalkers in the future (Niv-Mizzet. It would take comic book logic, but Wizards is more than up to that.)

I'm inclined to say that the ''weakest'' of the Guilds by Strength of Paruns or by Number of times Leadership has changed are Simic, Gruul, and Azorius

The most powerful are without a doubt Rakdos, Boros, and Orzhov

The two with wildly far-reaching potential physically and magically are Golgari and Dimir, but their real strength is quite defined by how aggressive and how naturally powerful the Guildmaster is at the time. Rakdos, Boros, and Orzhov beat the reast of the Guilds because their Guildmasters are the most Immortal, most Magical, and most Physically intimidating all at once. Isperia might be almost on their footing, though.

It's not that I don't respect Izzet or Selesnya, but they've actually been the most relatively restrained, which accounts for their high marks in Stability, and I don't see either of them going way, but I don't see either of them taking over either. Niv-Mizzet aims to disprove me.

Final Note: there's a teeny tiny chance that Simic and Gruul, both being Green, can trace their Guildmasters to Super Godlike Monster Paruns- Gruul seems to believe in a Boar God, and a Giant Leviathan of Simic is not unimaginable. These would place them level with, I think, Golgari and Dimir, but they'd have to be REALLY impressive BEASTS to make me think A Demon, an Angel, and a Ghost Council actually could lose in a fight to them.

Some people think Niv-Mizzet is, like, as cool and therefore unstoppable as Nicol Bolas. Flat B.S. He's as ambitious, but he's way too young, naive, and merciful to be compared to Nicol Bolas. He'll never be that powerful because he's too religiously committed to Red and Blue to gain any more colors. 3 colors, 20,000 years seniority, a Planeswalker spark, plus being from a stronger line of Dragon blood mean Bolas outclasses him even in his decrepit senile years, when Niv-Mizzet is at his zenith.

Szadek the Vampire got beat by a dead human cop. Yeah, it was his plan all along, but that seems like a strange plan that wouldn't be necessary if he had enough brute force. Physically, but not Magically, relatively Weak.

107096: Mizzium Transreliquat.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
107096: Mizzium Transreliquat.text_parsed:
I didn't see any consensus in these posts, so I checked the web for a ruling, and found an answer by Camper11 on the MTG Salvation forums. It was posted in 2009, but it matches the text in the current comprehensive rules.

Unfortunately, Luke_BPC and Razbot are right. When an ability mentions "the exiled item", it is always linked with the previous ability that exiled the item. The ability will only work with items that were exiled with the linked imprint ability, not other imprint abilities. So when new abilities are gained, those new ones won't link to the old.

Current rulings (MagicCompRules 2013/11/01)

607.1. An object may have two abilities printed on it such that one of them causes actions to be taken or objects or players to be affected and the other one directly refers to those actions, objects, or players. If so, these two abilities are linked: the second refers only to actions that were taken or objects or players that were affected by the first, and not by any other ability.

607.2a If an object has an activated or triggered ability printed on it that instructs a player to exile one or more cards and an ability printed on it that refers either to "the exiled cards" or to cards "exiled with ," these abilities are linked. The second ability refers only to cards in the exile zone that were put there as a result of an instruction to exile them in the first ability.
107096: Mizzium Transreliquat.text_posted:
I didn't see any consensus in these posts, so I checked the web for a ruling, and found an answer by Camper11 on the MTG Salvation forums. It was posted in 2009, but it matches the text in the current comprehensive rules.

Unfortunately, Luke_BPC and Razbot are right. When an ability mentions "the exiled item", it is always linked with the previous ability that exiled the item. The ability will only work with items that were exiled with the linked imprint ability, not other imprint abilities. So when new abilities are gained, those new ones won't link to the old.

Current rulings (MagicCompRules 2013/11/01)

[b]607.1.[/b] An object may have two abilities printed on it such that one of them causes actions to be taken or objects or players to be affected and the other one directly refers to those actions, objects, or players. If so, these two abilities are linked: the second refers only to actions that were taken or objects or players that were affected by the first, and not by any other ability.

[b]607.2a [/b]If an object has an activated or triggered ability printed on it that instructs a player to exile one or more cards and an ability printed on it that refers either to "the exiled cards" or to cards "exiled with [this object]," these abilities are linked. The second ability refers only to cards in the exile zone that were put there as a result of an instruction to exile them in the first ability.

107098: Gruul War Plow.author: Doublestack
107098: Gruul War Plow.text_parsed:
BDradon123 makes perfect sense when you look from what I assume is his point of view.

He takes Trample to mean two separate instances of assigning damage which, considering Anthem of Rakdos' wording, would each be doubled twice.

So, what we have is the following:

A 1/1 gets +4/+0 from the two anthems, becoming a 5/1 with trample, due to the Warplow, and attacks. It is then blocked by a 1/1. It is at this point that, using BDragon123's interpretation of the rules, that the 5/1 deals damage to the creature, which is doubled twice (5x2x2 = 20). So 20 damage is dealt to the 1/1, crushing it into oblivion. However, since the creature has trample, 19 damage gets through to the player. This is very important since BDragon123 considers this to be another instance of dealing damage which would then be doubled twice, again.

So we have 19x2 = 38, 38x2=76. So 76 damage if BDragon123's interpretation of how trample combined with Anthem's damage doubling ability would work is correct.

Does anyone know for sure? The 702.19 rulings word trample as dealing damage first to the creature, then to the player. From those words I think BDragon123 has his head on straight after all!

107680: Leap of Flame.author: Magnor_Criol
107680: Leap of Flame.text_parsed:
I think it works better if you see it as two separate cards - 1R to give a creature +1/0 and first strike, and 1U to give a creature +1/+0 and flying. The first can be used as a combat trick to remove a creature, the second can be used to get damage through. They just combined them into one card for us.

Useful utility card, and the replicate makes it potentially backbreaking in the right situations. Solid 3.5/5.

@Imperialstonedragon: like Magnor_Criol said, it has flying for attacking, and first strike for defending. Ilarious that red provides a difensive ability and blue an attacking ability... For such a flexibility and surprise factor, this card can be very swingy, taking down a couple of creature in the opponent start a risky attack or delivery a mass evasion attack...

If you ever tried it in a UR creature deck, you could have tested its power...! Easily 4/5 or more...

Edit: thinking about it a second time, I changed my idea... Both flying and first strike aren't exclusive offensive or defensive abilities. With Leap of Flames I can block a flying creature with an un-flying one. Or I can pump a blocked creature of mine to kill the blocking one... This flexibility makes this card very useful!

107682: Leyline of the Void.author: Corey_bayoudragonfly
107682: Leyline of the Void.text_parsed: @dybeck: Definitely an important sideboard card in eternal formats.  A lot of decks in the metagame of Legacy are crippled by this (e.g. Dredge, Reanimator, Breakfast, Tog, Loam), and so are several in Vintage.  I wouldn't say this -- or graveyard hate in general -- is too narrow.  Like any good sideboard card (except some kinds of wish targets), it depends on the deck you're running and the metagame, but that's how sideboards operate.  That's not the same as being narrow, not that narrow cards can't also be reasonably run in the right metagame.

107683: Gruul Nodorog.author: nemokara
107683: Gruul Nodorog.text_parsed:
If this were printed today, it would probably be one mana cheaper, and would be an average common: probably solid in casual/Limited (depending on the rest of the set it's in) and generally not of any use in Standard or eternal formats. We wouldn't usually expect it to be, either. So to compare it to cards that are good or even staples in non-Limited formats is somewhat disengenuous. Here are some more appropriate comparisons from recent sets:

Rubbleback Rhino
Grizzled Outcasts
Vastwood Gorger
Pathbreaker Wurm
Sentinel Spider
Fangren Marauder
Alpha Tyrranax
Garruk's Packleader
Howlgeist
Spinebiter
Stingerfling Spider

These were all at least playable in their Limited environments (and some were legitimate bombs). This would be about middle of the pack in power level for a top-of-the-curve creature in green, or slightly below-average if reprinted in a core set: sometimes just okay, sometimes quite good, sometimes cut from your deck altogether.

Bottom line - I won't ever be looking for copies of this for one of my EDH/casual decks, but I can respect its niche in the game.

107686: Leyline of Lightning.text_posted: I believe that you can only pay 1 colorless mana per spell, The question that I have is, can you play a card that has replicate such as [autocard]Train of Thought[/autocard] and then pay an additional colorless mana for each time the spell was [b]replicated[/b]?

107686: Leyline of Lightning.author: Falgorn
107686: Leyline of Lightning.text_parsed: Nope, you can't take advantage of spells with replicate. You can only take advantage of copies when the effect creating them specifically states that you cast them. For example, Spellweaver Volute and Chandra Ablaze's ultimate work with Leyline of Lightning, whereas a leveled-up Echo Mage doesn't.
107686: Leyline of Lightning.text_posted: Nope, you can't take advantage of spells with replicate. You can only take advantage of copies when the effect creating them specifically states that you [u]cast[/u] them. For example, [autocard]Spellweaver Volute[/autocard] and [autocard]Chandra Ablaze[/autocard]'s ultimate work with [autocard]Leyline of Lightning[/autocard], whereas a leveled-up [autocard]Echo Mage[/autocard] doesn't.

107686: Leyline of Lightning.author: alphagprime
107686: Leyline of Lightning.text_parsed: Here is why this card is good. Check out Lightning Bolt, Shock, and Burst Lightning. According to Wizards 1 cmc is worth 2-3 damage but 4 burn damage is worth 5 cmc in the case of Burst Lightning at instant speed or 5 damage for 5cmc at Sorcery speed. How about 4 damage for 2cmc at instant speed? Doesn't sound to bad now not to mention no matter what you cast you can guarantee you ping your opponents life total for one and that can make a difference especially if you aren't pulling all the cards you want or don't have the mana to play every card you want. Not to mention this was originally a Ravnica card. Pair this up with two Gelectrodes and your 1{R} Lightning bolt for 3 becomes a 2{R} torrent for 8 damage.

107689: Beastmaster's Magemark.author: DarthParallax
107689: Beastmaster's Magemark.text_parsed:
Just realized- the Magemarks are actually a vey interesting take on counteracting Aura 'card disadvantage'-

While trying to maximize them by enchanting lots of creatures is not completely safe (you'll definitely need to find some way to Wrath-proof them), a Magemark Deck can get lots of incremental card quality advantage, so that if it really starts firing, ONLY a Wrath can save the opponent- which if you're prepared for, can lead to some great blow-out wins :)

This cycle is about half a star better than it looks if you build a focused deck for it.

107692: Starved Rusalka.author: Mode
107692: Starved Rusalka.text_parsed:
Making a vertical cycle where one color variant gains you much life as another deals damage to a player might seem right due to symmetry, but it's a terrible design choice. Which probably explains the abysmal rating:

Compare then to the following red/white pairs of other vertical cycles for example:
- Zuberas: Ember-Fist Zubera/Silent-Chant Zubera
- Mirrodin Spellbombs: Pyrite Spellbomb/Lifespark Spellbomb
- Ordeals: Ordeal of Purphoros/Ordeal of Heliod
That's a ratio of 1 (2, 3) damage to 2 (5, 10) life. And the damage can even be directed at a creature in all cases.

So it's probably the frustation about this fact that made her end up with a rating worse than Willow Elf.

After all, Willow Elf just happens to be one of many harmless, crappy yet forgetful vanilla 1/1s.
Starved Rusalka, on the other hand, is part of a particular cycle and an offender of tauntingly underpowered design.

107694: Primeval Light.author: endersblade
107694: Primeval Light.text_parsed:
You guys arguing over which is technically better than the other are silly. They all fill different needs.

Calming Verse
Primeval Light
Spring Cleaning
Cleansing Meditation

These sorts of cards are meant to be run in enchantment heavy decks, but for taking out all opposing enchantments while leaving yours intact.

Tranquility
Back to Nature
Tranquil Grove
Tempest of Light

These sorts of cards are meant to be run in decks that have little to no enchantments, or don't care about losing them.

Again, each 'type' of card has its niche. I tend to rely heavily on enchantments, so I fill my (EDH) decks with the first type, so mine stay safe.

Is Primeval Light 'strictly better' than Tranq? Depends on how you look at it. At least Primeval Light saves your own enchantments. If you don't care about that, then Tranq is better. But this card is not the be-all-end-all over Tranq, for sure.

107695: Leyline of Lifeforce.author: Lyoncet
107695: Leyline of Lifeforce.text_parsed:
This is one of those great-on-paper, meh-in-practice cards in my opinion. In terms of pros and cons, you have:

Pros
Totally messes with the greatest enemy of green's patented Big Damn Creatures strategy (perhaps I'm an exception here, but my attempts at green are more often frustrated by MUC/UWC than mass destruction)

One of the only cards (along with the rest of its cycle) that sneaks in under Force of Will - VERY useful

Cons
Like all leylines, a bit pricey if it's not in your opening hand

Only protects your creatures, so if you try to throw a Naturalize on your opponent's Leyline of Anticipation, or if you're a bad bad person and running 4 Berserks, this won't protect them

Doesn't protect against counters that don't say the word "counter," like Mindbreak Trap and Time Stop

Still vulnerable to removal, and can be removed easily by the one deck it's meant to counter. Even if you run and somehow play four of them, you're just one Echoing Truth away from being put behind by 14 mana and having your summon countered. And with Echoing Truth being one of the best bounces in the game, and an enormously strong card in general, it seems pretty likely you'll be going up against 4 in any deck you'd run this against.

Nothing's preventing this spell from being countered, although that does put your opponent down a counterspell (in which case you may as well use an Autumn's Veil for 3 less)


With the few pros and very damning cons, the greatest of which is that it's easily countered by the very thing it's supposed to counter, I can't rate this above a 3. Compare to something like Leyline of Sanctity, which is meant to hose red burn and actually does - perhaps too well. This one is too specific, and even if you only sideboard them, that's a few sideboard slots you're very unlikely to get much use of as opposed to something like Tectonic Edge which will help you against any number of decks (just to name one). The effect is great; it's usefulness is questionable.

107695: Leyline of Lifeforce.author: TheWrathofShane
107695: Leyline of Lifeforce.text_parsed:
Its a sideboard card. It could win you games against a blue deck, but a blue deck could still very well beat you with this using a bounce. They cannot counter this if its in your opening hand, because you never casted it, rather began the game with it.

The problem with the leylines, you only want one out and in your hand, but you want 4 in your deck to take advantage of the ability. Leyline of Vitality is an exception, but I feel the next leyline cycle needs to have, well cycling attached to them.

107696: Martyred Rusalka.author: Silverware
107696: Martyred Rusalka.text_parsed:
Completly agree with JL_Weber here, besides I try not to hang to much relevence on the art of a card since I have seen artists really mess up the art, as is the case with Hyalopterous Lemure.

Personaly I really do like the flavor of this card, it is kinda neat how it seems like she is trying to prevent any injustices from befalling anyone else, and so stoping someone from attacking effectivly lays her spirit to rest.

As far as how functional this card is..well it really is somewhat hard to say, I guess if you want your creatures in the graveyard this might be a good card. This comboed with festering goblin might be able to kill a few creatures early game. But all in all, usally tapping a creatures is more usefull then simply making it unable to attack. I would say it is a decent card, just not a great one.

107696: Martyred Rusalka.author: Mistralis
107696: Martyred Rusalka.text_parsed:
Don't try to put it in a deck that it doesn't work with. It's the kind of card that has its own small niche. Obviously, this is the sacrifice one.
I have a B/W sacrifice deck (make a bunch of tokens, use sacrifice outlets to trigger Morbid things like Skirsdag High Priest and Tragic Slip while things like Unruly Mob get ridiculous).
Then, I saw this card. I thought "Meh, I'll give it a shot" and bought one.
The next day, I was playing a game with it, and this thing kept me in the game. I was mana screwed so I had no blockers, and this managed to let me stall until I could cast an Increasing Devotion.

All in all, it's only good if you have a deck that'll work with it. The only ones that are probably going to work are this one and Plagued Rusalka. The rest are in strange colors.

I'm not sure if this is correct or not (not a pro judge or anything) but even if they declare something as an attacker, if you use this, it will still be tapped as it will be an attacker, but won't actually attack as it cannot. May be wrong. Either way, this thing is a deterrent, makes your opponent either pass or attack with everything if you've setup right.

107697: Leyline of Singularity.author: Kitty_the_Kat
107697: Leyline of Singularity.text_parsed:
Use this with Leyline of Anticipation in EDH and you have very good set-up for tons of degenerate combos. Clones and similar abilities become the best creature removal available. Use your Phyrexian Metamorph to take out Sol Ring, Lightning Greaves, and Caged Sun.

I plan on using both of these with Damia, Sage of Stone as my general. Between these cards and Words of Waste I'll have plenty of opportunities to control the game.

107697: Leyline of Singularity.author: Paragalor
107697: Leyline of Singularity.text_parsed:
So many combos you can do with this. My teacher has a U/B deck based around this beauty with a few annoying tricks:

Clone = Destroy target creature.
Empress Galina = Gain control of target permanent.
Cryptoplasm = At the beginning of your upkeep, you may destroy target creature.
Blood Seeker = Whenever you play Hunted Horror, target opponent loses 2 life. Whenever you play Hunted Phantasm, target opponent loses 5 life.
Hunted Horror = : 7/7 w/ trample. BS makes target opponent lose 2 life.
Hunted Phantasm = : 4/6 unblockable. BS makes target opponent lose 5 life.

I love that deck.

107697: Leyline of Singularity.author: A_Real_Travesty
107697: Leyline of Singularity.text_parsed:
Deck I recently put together revolves around this.

U/B Leyline Reanimation:

Leyline of Singularity, Leyline of the Void, Grave Pact, Reassembling Skeleton, Gravecrawler, and Death Baron.

With Singularity and Grave Pact, your dead Skeletons become "Pay 4: each opponent sacrifices 2 creatures." Get Death Baron or any other zombie out, and your dead Gravecrawlers become "Pay 2: each opponent sacs 2 creatures." Throw out the other Leyline, and now it's exile instead of sac.

With Singularity and Grave Pact, your dead Skeletons become "Pay 4: each opponent sacrifices 2 creatures."  Get Death Baron or any other zombie out, and your dead Gravecrawlers become "Pay 2: each opponent sacs 2 creatures."  Throw out the other Leyline, and now it's exile instead of sac.

But, there's plenty of creatures able to do so.. Nantuko Husk, as a great example.. Sacrifice a creature: Nantuko Husk gets +2/+2 until end of turn.. Infinite power, toughness and minions to abuse to the fullest! ;D

83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.author: Titobaube
83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.text_parsed:
Hello Jenss,
If you got Darkest Hour in play and Teysa, you can sacrifice three white creature to remove another creature from the game and put three white creature into play that you can sacrifice again to remove another creature from the game and so forth. When you're done you still have almost all your creature and your opponents have nothing! Who needs an infinite loop when you can whipe your opponents board.

And if you want to go infinite you can still do it with those 2 cards because You activate the first ability by sacrificing 3 creature, which triggers the effect of putting three other creature into play before the "remove target creature from the game" (Exile) effect resolve. You can activate it again and again before letting any of them resolve!

83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.author: Zoah
83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.text_parsed:
Combo or no, She's a fantastic card. Cost wise, she is very low for a card like this.

Already she's a three cost for a 2/3 which isn't bad...

Also, neither of her ability require her to tap and one of them is a triggered ability. I could start listing ideas for decks to put her in, but that would take too long.

So advantages: her cost and color weight allows her to be played early and easily, Her first ability is easily triggered and produces an excellent effect, and her second ability is fueled by her first and also produces an excellent effect. Both abilities allow room for combos (with each other or not) and even outside of a deck build for her, she is still great.

Also, if the right creature dies (something like Bile Urchin) it may wind up better than before!

Why is the ghost counsel of Orzhovah rated higher than her? By themselves they are virtually useless. There grunts, for attacking and defending, and little else. They provide little chance for combos and serve little purpose but to sit there and not die.

So:

Base ranking: ***

slightly off in reference to manna vs stats: -*/2
slight color requirements: -*/2
Activated ability: +*
Triggered ability: +**

Final ranking: *****
83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.text_posted:
Combo or no, She's a fantastic card. Cost wise, she is very low for a card like this.

Already she's a three cost for a 2/3 which isn't bad...

Also, neither of her ability require her to tap and one of them is a triggered ability. I could start listing ideas for decks to put her in, but that would take too long.

So advantages: her cost and color weight allows her to be played early and easily, Her first ability is easily triggered and produces an excellent effect, and her second ability is fueled by her first and also produces an excellent effect. Both abilities allow room for combos (with each other or not) and even outside of a deck build for her, she is still great.

Also, if the right creature dies (something like Bile Urchin) it may wind up better than before!

Why is the ghost counsel of Orzhovah rated higher than her? By themselves they are virtually useless. There grunts, for attacking and defending, and little else. They provide little chance for combos and serve little purpose but to sit there and not die.

So:

Base ranking: ***

slightly off in reference to manna vs stats: -*/2
slight color requirements: -*/2

Final ranking: *****

83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.author: UltimaCenturion
83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.text_parsed:
Exuberence, Titobaube, you need more than that to complete the combo. She can only sacrifice creatures who are white, and darkest hour makes them black and ONLY black. She also can't increase the number of spirit tokens there are on the field, which you would need to do to be able to sac more than three to Altar of Dementia.
He would be better off running Altar of Dementia in a Rhys the Redeemed deck with a lot of infinite mana combos (one of the elves that tap for a mana per elf along with Sword of the Paruns would work.) Or, even better, just run grinding stone and Painter's Servant. Of course, Painter's Servent is banned in EDH, so you wouldn't be able to run it in every game format.
Sadly, I run her as a general, and she isn't that great. I rarely feel like playing her, and I don't have enough white creatures to run with her, or anything to really synergize with her. (Shirei would work. All you would need is 3 1 or less power white creatures that aren't tokens (as tokens are RFGed when they hit the grave.) Throw in Twilight drover for a hideously enormous monster!)

83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.author: aPulseRemains
83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.text_parsed:
This card with 2 Nether Traitor and a Phyrexian Altar. Probably one of the simplest infinite token combos in the game.

Dark Ritual up a Traitor turn one, play the second one on turn two, play Teysa on turn 3, and a Phyrexian Altar on turn 4. You probably just won the game.

Or, if you're feeling especially twisted, use that extra mana from the turn 1 Ritual to play a Blood Pet, then sac it turn 3 for another Dark Ritual and the Altar on turn 3 instead of turn 4.
83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.text_posted:
This card with 2 [autocard]Nether Traitor[/autocard] and a [autocard]Phyrexian Altar[/autocard].  Probably one of the simplest infinite token combos in the game.

Or, if you're feeling especially twisted, use that extra mana from the turn 1 Ritual to play a [autocard]Blood Pet[/autocard], then sac it turn 3 for another Dark Ritual and the Altar on turn 3 instead of turn 4.

83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.author: Kezia
83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.text_parsed:
Teysa Karlov

The main character of the Guildpact novel. Equal parts ambition and execution. With a few well-chosen words and a couple of well-planned smiles, she can make practically anyone dance to her tune. She is an Orzhov advokist (lawyer), but retires early to become the baroness of the Utvara region. She also makes an appearance in the Dissension novel. (Card:Teysa, Orzhov Scion)

http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Magic:_The_Gathering_characters:_T#section_35

83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.author: Enelysios
83546: Teysa, Orzhov Scion.text_parsed:
I had her as a general for a while, because I love her character, but she was terribly unfun for my opponents. The amount of removal she alone provides is annoying. Opponent plays their general? (Most cost more than 3 mana) Remove it. Opponent plays a big fatty? Remove it. Your creatures about to die in combat? Sacrifice them. On top of her, white and black have the game's best removal spells. The deck ended up being very non-interactive.

Of course Teysa is a great card and I won't hold my deck against her. She just encourages some annoying play.

83739: To Arms!.author: HairlessThoctar
83739: To Arms!.text_parsed:
This might be my favorite white instant to date.
Fantastic art.
A name with an exclamation point.
Effect with nigh endless applications; from combat shenanigans to getting stupid amounts of mana from your mana dorks.
Fairly costed, and then they throw in a cantrip.
And not just a line, but a whole story for flavor text.
Certainly more powerful cards out there, but this seems more fun.

Only two problems;
One: Why hasn't this become a core set staple?
Two: Why won't this system let me rate it higher than 5?

83869: Angel of Despair.author: Gaussgoat
83869: Angel of Despair.text_parsed:
Have you met my friend Dark Ritual? Or perhaps my other friend, Dark Ritual?

Black has tons of mana acceleration outside of Standard, so this rather destructive lady could find her way to the battlefield in a hurry. Hell, you could drop her with a Dance of the Dead from your own graveyard, or one of a million other animate effects that are available.

The basic card is a bomb. Expensive, but obviously effective.

4/5

83869: Angel of Despair.author: sarroth
83869: Angel of Despair.text_parsed:
@Alicanto: I'm not sure how Muse Vessel works in this situation. The vessel allows you to play a card exiled with it, but does not allow you to play it without paying it's mana cost. So you're paying {3} to exile it and {1} plus {3}{W}{W}{B}{B} in order to play the card.

Angel of Despair is a little expensive, even for my tastes, but the art, P/T, and abilities (destroy and flying) cater to the Timmy in me.

96825: Silhana Ledgewalker.author: achilleselbow
96825: Silhana Ledgewalker.text_parsed: I used to play my friend's Jund deck with some decks I built out of old Ravnica block cards I had. Of course, the power levels were completely uneven and I got sick of having all my creatures Terminated or Maelstrom Pulsed. So I threw together a Golgari deck featuring this girl, Moldervine Cloak, Shambling Shell, and Wurmweaver Coil to power her up, Gather Courage to power up and protect her from Jund Charm when my friend thinks I'm tapped out, Shred Memory to tutor for her if I don't get her in my opening hand, and packed the rest with removal like Last Gasp and Putrefy. Worked like a charm.
96825: Silhana Ledgewalker.text_posted: I used to play my friend's Jund deck with some decks I built out of old Ravnica block cards I had. Of course, the power levels were completely uneven and I got sick of having all my creatures [autocard]Terminate[/autocard]d or [autocard]Maelstrom Pulse[/autocard]d. 96825: Silhana Ledgewalker.author: Gabriel422
96825: Silhana Ledgewalker.text_parsed:
This works differently than Flying: it's more like she gains Flying when she attacks. And flavorfully it makes sense: she's not exactly flying, only walking on roofs, but it definitely takes a flying creature to stop her.

As for the card, I've definitely had fun Moldervine Cloaking her and handing her some Loxodon Warhammers (really brutal). When she appeared on the other side, well, the very fact that my friend plays her incentivized me to put Pyroclasm in my decks. I like green creatures with troll shroud, but I believe we definitely need more playable cards to deal with them, especially at common and uncommon. (like an uncommon conditional Wrath variant)
96825: Silhana Ledgewalker.text_posted:

96825: Silhana Ledgewalker.author: mattblack04
96825: Silhana Ledgewalker.text_parsed: Forgive me if it wouldn't work out so well in paper magic, but in the video game 2012 version, this card is an enchantment queen. 96825: Silhana Ledgewalker.author: ax_morph
96825: Silhana Ledgewalker.text_parsed:
This may be the best common green creature ever printed.

It's an Elf. It's a Rogue. It has all the benefits of flying and none of the downsides. It can't be blocked by Spiders and Archers. It doesn't die to Doom Blade, but is ready to accept everything from Gather Courage to Wurmweaver Coil. Ledgewalker has the capacity to win games. All for a measly two mana. I wish I could rate this higher than 5 stars.

96826: Quicken.author: Mode
96826: Quicken.text_parsed:
You can give any sorcery wanted instant-speed for one tiny blue mana with that. Sounds like a fair trade.
It also in some way slightly shrinkens the deck size, but as ttian said, that's rather negligible normally^^

A cheap cantrip like this can of course also be useful if you run cards that profit from drawing.

And as Vektor hinted, Isochron Scepter is another card that works nice with that card as well.

I also like the fact that they printed a white version of this for creatures.

@Hydrogoose and ttian: I concede that mentioning the shrinking option was rather dumb and is most often negligible, but i was thinking about the Baubles at that time, which can sorta shrink your deck at the cost of a delayed card draw to increase the chance of getting the cards you want for several desired combos. Of course this isn't worth the effort in most cases, but Hydrogoose apparently didn't get that one, since Glimpse doesn't really work that way.

96826: Quicken.author: Annoyilator
96826: Quicken.text_parsed:
QUESTION: Does Quicken work on Equip costs on artifacts already on the battlefield? I only ask because those equip costs are so often specifically described as being playable only when you can play a sorcery.

Here's my reasoning: You play Quicken. Assuming it resolves without being countered, at that moment, you are now "at a time you can play a sorcery" or you can then "Equip ***AS A*** Sorcery"? Right?

If that's right, think of all the horrifying surprises you can give an opponent during his/her turn when they think a particularly annoying piece of equipment is out of play because it's not equipped to a creature when your turn ends or the creature to which it is attached is tapped. Surestrike Trident suddenly lands on a key defender of yours, enabling you to tap and hit your opponent directly at a vulnerable moment. Or perhaps one of those hexproof-providing artifacts suddenly lands on the defender your opponent is targeting with some nasty spell during his turn. I'm not a pro, so I'm sure you guys can think of much deadlier combos with Equipment (assuming my reading of the application of Quicken is right).

96826: Quicken.author: Gulltralisk
96826: Quicken.text_parsed:
@Pyromage1222

Yes, it would work. The gut shot was on the stack before the Worldfire was cast at instant speed because of the Quicken. Worldfire doesn't remove spells from the stack, so the Gut Shot was still waiting to resolve after the Worldfire resolved, so as soon as the Gut Shot resolves, unless he pulls off some lifegain, the opponent loses.

The Sudden Disappearance didn't work because Sudden Disappearance is a sorcery and as such can't be placed on the stack above other spells without the help of something like Quicken. If you had cast the Disappearance before the worldfire, it would have worked. If you had given the Disappearance flash, it would have worked.

96827: Repeal.author: Salient
96827: Repeal.text_parsed:
It was cool to read the comments and discover the token-destruction potential for this card -- thanks, Test Subject! -- but in my experience it has a more boring traditional purpose: this card sees Vintage play in Storm decks, because it cantrips for to bounce your Mana Crypt or Mox or whatever for repeat mana acceleration.

It's the truest cantrip, basically paying for itself by letting you replay a mana acceleration artifact. The net effect is +2 storm, sort of without expending cards (since repeal replaces itself) or mana (since you're getting to play and tap the bounced Mox a second time). Yeah, you're usually replaying Mox Ruby or whatever and getting instead of , but this is still as close to perfect cantripping as Vintage Storm can get.

The hilarious thing is, in Vintage you'd always use this to destroy your own tokens, never an opponent's -- nobody really uses cards to give themselves tokens, but decks using Oath of Druids try to dump a stupid token on you (with Forbidden Orchard type effects) so that they can Oath up their star quarterback. Apparently Repeal is anti-Oath tech!

96829: Electrolyze.author: DoctorKenneth
96829: Electrolyze.text_parsed:
TheDarkOne: It was updated to prevent people thinking they could target, say, eight of your opponent's creatures for 0 damage and two of them for 1 damage with a Cowardice in play.

ttian: I don't think "strictly worse" means what you think it means. If this was a Prodigal Pyromancer that was a 0/1 instead of 1/1, that would be strictly worse. This is an instant that splits damage, and is useful for combat tricks that your opponent won't see coming, unlike the 1/1 pinger that's in plain view across the table.

leo: Fire costs 1R. Single card draw plus minor benefit is U. The minor benefit in this case? You use one card, not two, for the same effect. Look, it's really hard to mash cards together and think that the costs become balanced. It doesn't happen. If it did, RR would buy you a double Lightning Bolt for 6 (or even Shock for 4). Thankfully, it does not.

This is actually deceptively useful, as Akatosh has said. The fact that it cantrips is brilliant, and you can often 2-for 1, taking out annoying utility creatures or tokens. A blue/red deck, it's going to be counter/burn heavy, and you want to keep your hand stocked. If you are making a U/R deck, make sure you have ways to either recurr your instants and sorceries, copy them to get more spell per card, or make sure your hand stays full with cards like this.

96833: Gristleback.author: marmaris74
96833: Gristleback.text_parsed:
It stll pains me to tell the story, but I'll try:
It was the summer of 2008. Gristleback, bloodthirst enabled, had just entered the battlefield. He was young and eager to fight, though he felt too summoning sick to do so. When our controller passed the turn, I thought Gristly might be safe. How foolish was I.
Our opponent attacked. To my horror, Gristly was commanded to block. I tried to stop him, told him he wasn't ready to fight yet, but Gristleback insisted on charging onto the front lines.
The battle was crazy. Lightning Bolts were flying left and right. One barely missed Gristly, hitting a nearby flagbearer instead. Gristleback smashed through a skeleton, only for it to reassemble behind him. I was very relieved to see he was safe.
The next turn, our owner told Gristleback to block a pride of lions. With a vines of vastwood in hand, this move was a logical one. But when our enemy tried to terrorize my other good friend Tarmogoyf, the vines were used for his protection. Gristleback looked at my owner in shock. I had never seen a creature feel so abandoned. The Lions encircled Gristly, ready to devour him. Luckily, the Lions' owner commanded them to bypass Gristly and hit my owner directly. It was a hard hit, lowering my owner to 4 life, but Gristleback was safe! I remember crying tears of joy.
The next turn, I faintly remember hearing my owner muttering about "making sacrifices." At the time, I thought little of his words. But, the next turn, I remember untapping to find that my loyal friend was gone.
Save a beast. Eat a gelfruit.
--Diary of a Young Beastbreaker

@Lash_of_Dragonbreath
Good call. I guess the story scarred me so much I'm having trouble remembering the details. I think it must have happened in 2011.

The next turn, our owner told Gristleback to block a [autocard]pride of lions[/autocard]. With a [autocard]vines of vastwood[/autocard] in hand, this move was a logical one. But when our enemy tried to [autocard]terror[/autocard]ize my other good friend [autocard]Tarmogoyf[/autocard], the vines were used for his protection. Gristleback looked at my owner in shock. I had never seen a creature feel so abandoned. The Lions encircled Gristly, ready to devour him. Luckily, the Lions' owner commanded them to bypass Gristly and hit my owner directly. It was a hard hit, lowering my owner to 4 life, but Gristleback was safe! I remember crying tears of joy.
The next turn, I faintly remember hearing my owner muttering about "making sacrifices." At the time, I thought little of his words. But, the next turn, I remember untapping to find that my loyal friend was gone.
Save a beast. Eat a [autocard multiverseid="46076"]gelfruit[/autocard].
  --Diary of a Young [autocard multiverseid="193638"]Beastbreaker[/autocard]

@Lash_of_Dragonbreath
Good call. I guess the story scarred me so much I'm having trouble remembering the details. I think it must have happened in 2011.

Use a lot of land that sacrifice themselves (Depletion Land) or give themselves to your opponent (Rainbow Vale) along with 4 Delusions of Mediocrity and 4 Illusions of Grandeur. Bronze Bombshells are pretty good for this too. And since the deck is mono-blue, you can run plenty of counter magic. 96835: Sky Swallower.author: VoidedNote
96835: Sky Swallower.text_parsed:
Bottom line, this card is terrible on its own. Easily the worst of all the blue fatties.

If you combo with it though, it can be a decent investment. 5 for an 8/8 flier is a good deal. However, chances are you're going to spend more than 3 mana trying to combo it so at best you're going to get 8 mana and TWO cards for an 8/8 flier.

I'd stick with Goliath Sphinx because at least that isn't a dead card if it gets put back in your hand.

1.5/5. More of a fun card, but really not worth it in any format.

96835: Sky Swallower.author: N3rf
96835: Sky Swallower.text_parsed:
Combo with mindslaver and soul foundry. Imprint the sky swallower under the soul foundtry, play the mindslaver. Hand over the turn with atleast 4 mana open and during his turn activate the mindslaver. In your own turn following that, activate soul foundry, handing over every permanent including the soul foundry with the sky swallower imprinted.

Hand over the turn again and laugh maniacally as you activate 'his' soul foundry again to take control over everything, including all the stuff you gave him, leaving behind an 8/8 flyer (that you incidentally ALSO have!).

Add artifact recurrence for the mind slaver (academy ruins buried ruin are my favorites, but non-land versions also work ofcourse), some tutoring (tinker treasure mage for example) and any kind of mana accelerate (remember, the entire combo is colorless, you dont actually pay blue to play the sky swallower)!

This would actually make for a decent multiplayer or casual deck. Keep in mind that you are very vulnerable after you hand over your soul foundry. You can also use similiar effects such as mimic vat, but i doubt its possible to get that one working. The mind slaver effect (also provided by sorin markov) is essential.

Both Bazaar Trader and are required, but each Sapphire Medallion, Sunscape Familiar, or Nightscape Familiar you have reduces this cost by (you won't control them when you try to cast your second spell), and each Helm of Awakening on the board will reduce the cost by , down to a minimum of . High Tide might pull it off.
Cast Sky Swallower. In response the the trigger, float and use Bazaar Trader to donate the leviathan to your opponent. The trigger will then resolve, and your board will be empty.
Use Reins of Power and beat your opponent down with both your and his armies.
If you and your opponent together possess more than enough firepower to get the job done, then perhaps you might want to Sacrifice the Leviathan and/or any unnecessary creatures you might have to something in exchange for the necessary mana.

Watch out for [autocard]Disenchant[/autocard] in response to the [autocard]Sky Swallower[/autocard] or its triggered ability, though.

@ Arachibutyrophobia:  Challenge accepted.

Both [autocard]Bazaar Trader[/autocard] and [5UUUU] are required, but each [autocard]Sapphire Medallion[/autocard], [autocard]Sunscape Familiar[/autocard], or [autocard]Nightscape Familiar[/autocard] you have reduces this cost by [1] (you won't control them when you try to cast your second spell), and each [autocard]Helm of Awakening[/autocard] on the board will reduce the cost by [2], down to a minimum of [UUUU].  [autocard]High Tide[/autocard] might pull it off.
Cast [autocard]Sky Swallower[/autocard].  In response the the trigger, float [2UU] and use [autocard]Bazaar Trader[/autocard] to donate the leviathan to your opponent.  The trigger will then resolve, and your board will be empty.
Use [autocard]Reins of Power[/autocard] and beat your opponent down with both your and his armies.
If you and your opponent together possess more than enough firepower to get the job done, then perhaps you might want to [autocard]Sacrifice[/autocard] the Leviathan and/or any unnecessary creatures you might have to [autocard multiverseid="23226"]something[/autocard] in exchange for the necessary mana.

96835: Sky Swallower.author: blurrymadness
96835: Sky Swallower.text_parsed:
Torpor Orb does the trick, but I think the card is more fun if you find a way to use it legit; consider the old Psychatog tactic of Upheaval and add High Tide.

High tide T6, upheaval, drop the leviathan and give them *nothing*.

They now have 1 turn to dig a 1-mana kill spell (far and few between for an 8/8 flyer) before eating 8 to the face.

it's not even unreliable and can be combined with psychatog for alternate win conditions. You can even wait til T7, play an island after dropping the Swallower, and keep a Spell Pierce ready.


Aside from that you can use this guy next to Plague Spitter to make a "Spit or Swallow" deck..

96837: Gruul Guildmage.author: Saraneth888
96837: Gruul Guildmage.text_parsed:
I could see this being incredibly strong in limited environments. Even just threatening the 2nd ability makes attacking or blocking a nightmare because it can target anything. The first ability is obviously a bit more narrow, but the option to shoot 4 or 6 damage at the opponents face over a few turns in the late-game is a very powerful tool in limited.

I would compare this to Darkthicket Wolf. Obviously it has harder color-requirements in G/x decks that don't have red, but Gruul Guildmage's pump ability can target ANY creature, rather than only pumping himself (albeit for the cost of 1 additional mana), and to top it all off, he even has another useful ability, even if it is a bit narrow.

96841: Lionheart Maverick.author: Zuty
96841: Lionheart Maverick.text_parsed:
There is currently only one other 1/1 with Vigilance for 1 mana and that guy is an uncommon. ( Mystic Penitent )

A 1/1 for 1 is pretty much common place at this point. Tack on Vig and he's looking pretty good. The pump is very nice, but the expensive cost turns heads. Why should I spend 4W for +1/+2 when I can drop Gleam of Resistance which has the exact same cost, but is better all around? +1/+2 to itself is, at the most, worth 2W; even if that were the case for this card I have a suspicion people would still complain about it being to high of a price.

I say, ignore the self buff and look at the card again. A 1/1 for W with Vigilance and a relevant creature type that you can most certainly make good use of is a good card, even better so that it is sitting at a common slot. For that reason I am giving this card 4 stars. The pump should not turn heads and lower this guys score. The pump is not mandatory nor is it a draw back, so why rate this guy down because his pump, which you don't need to activate really ever, is over priced?

~Zuty

96841: Lionheart Maverick.author: MacBizzle
96841: Lionheart Maverick.text_parsed:
Those of you that talk about how useless the second ability is or how "you just want to white it out and run auras" need to learn about mana dumps, card slots and card advantage.

First of all, aura decks are notoriously bad from a card advantage perspective. Creature removal is the most notorious of all removals (all colors have it in some fashion, most decks worth playing have it) and you're PUTTING MORE CARDS onto a creature. If you're running auras that give hexproof, then great. But what about late game? When you're out of cards in your hand, slowly drawing your deck, card by card, not getting a necessary buff for your guy to get through?

That's where this guy comes in. He buffs HIMSELF, no cards wasted. You don't need to draw anything else, you don't need to put any late game buffs in the deck because in the late game with an empty hand, you'll want something to use all that mana on. These are called mana dumps, and the idea behind them is the capability of making good use of your mana, even when you're empty handed. If you compare him to a shade, you will be disappointed. However, this guy comes out on the first turn, and NOBODY EVER wastes a spell on him, due to the seemingly terrible appeal of the second ability.

If you have Dawnglare Invoker in the deck, you've already got a great mana dump. If not... consider this guy.

96842: Ghostway.author: Evermint
96842: Ghostway.text_parsed:
@Draycon

When end of turn comes around, all creatures come back at the same time. Whoever casted the spell gets priority in choosing when each creature comes into play after Ghostway's delayed trigger resolves. It's similar to having multiple end-of-turn triggers.

So if you Ghostway'd a Hada Freeblade, a Soul Warden and a kazandu blademaster, you could choose for the Soul Warden to come in before the Blademaster and Freeblade. Note while actually laying out the creatures, the spell has already resolved so people cannot, say, Lightning Bolt the Soul Warden if it comes out first while Ghostway is still resolving.
